study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the multifaceted effects of water-based treatments, including balneotherapy, on pain, inflammation, joint mobility, and overall well-being in patients with rheumatic diseases.
results_summary: The study found that balneotherapy and related water-based therapies effectively alleviate pain, reduce inflammation, improve joint mobility, and enhance physical and mental well-being in patients with rheumatic diseases. The therapies utilize water's thermal, mechanical, and chemical properties to regulate physiological and psycho-emotional states.
population_specificity: Patients with rheumatic diseases, including rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, and fibromyalgia syndrome.

study_goal: To investigate the influence of high-salinity geothermal mineral water baths on stress and fatigue reduction compared to music therapy and no treatment.
results_summary: Balneotherapy significantly reduced stress-related symptoms, pain, and fatigue while improving mood, cognitive function, and motivation, with effect sizes ranging from 0.8 to 2.3. It outperformed both music therapy (effect sizes 0.4–1.1) and the control group, which showed no significant improvements.
population_specificity: 180 seamen randomized into three groups (geothermal, music, control).
effective_dosage: 108 g/L salinity geothermal water bath, five times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the therapeutic effects of Nitrodi's water, focusing on its potential benefits for inflammatory and autoimmune conditions and age-related skin deterioration.
results_summary: Nitrodi's water demonstrated strong promotional effects on cell proliferation, migration, and viability, as well as anti-oxidant and anti-inflammatory properties, supporting its use in wound healing, tissue remodeling, and inflammatory conditions.
population_specificity: Epithelial cell models and historical clinical data (specific human populations not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding balneotherapy (BT) to standard physical therapy (PT) improves outcomes for chronic neck pain compared to PT alone.
results_summary: The study found that BT combined with PT was superior to PT alone in reducing pain and disability and improving quality of life in patients with chronic neck pain, with significant improvements in all measured parameters.
population_specificity: 60 patients with chronic neck pain (30 in the study group, 30 in the control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of balneotherapy, exercise, and their combination on fibromyalgia symptoms, including myalgic score, sleep quality, health status, and depression.
results_summary: The combined balneotherapy + exercise group showed significant improvements in total myalgic score, health status, and depression post-treatment, with sustained benefits at the third-month follow-up. Balneotherapy alone and combined therapy also improved sleep quality more effectively than exercise alone.
population_specificity: 120 female fibromyalgia patients (mean age 37.21±12.45 years, range 18-63).
effective_dosage: Five days a week for three weeks (specific balneotherapy dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Three weeks of intervention, with follow-up at three months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of hydrotherapy (balneotherapy) on plasma blood glucose levels in patients with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The review found that hydrotherapy, including hot and cold therapies, can be an effective intervention for managing blood glucose levels in type 2 diabetes, with potential benefits for reducing diabetes-related complications.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the use of physiotherapy, including balneotherapy, as an adjunct therapy for endometriosis to alleviate pain and improve quality of life.
results_summary: The study found that physiotherapy, including balneotherapy, can complement gynaecological treatment by reducing inflammation and pain, thereby improving the quality of life for women with endometriosis. The review highlighted various forms of physiotherapy but did not provide specific data on balneotherapy's isolated effects.
population_specificity: Women with endometriosis experiencing pelvic pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a standard rehabilitation program (including balneotherapy) versus a program incorporating the HUBER platform (also including balneotherapy) for improving outcomes in patients with non-specific chronic low back pain.
results_summary: Both intervention groups showed significant improvements in spine strength, flexibility, mobility, endurance, pain, and disability. The HUBER group demonstrated greater reductions in disability and improved spine flexion-to-extension ratio at higher speeds compared to the standard group.
population_specificity: Individuals with non-specific chronic low back pain (NSCLBP).
effective_dosage: 4 sessions of 2 hours each per week (combined with physiotherapy and either cycloergometer or HUBER exercises).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate factors associated with Length of Stay (LOS) in a transdisciplinary unit that included balneotherapy as part of rehabilitation for individuals after a suicide attempt by jumping.
results_summary: The study found that LOS in the transdisciplinary unit was primarily influenced by the severity of somatic injuries, with some psychiatric factors also playing a role. Balneotherapy was part of the rehabilitation approach, but its specific effects were not isolated in the results.
population_specificity: Men and women admitted after a suicide attempt by jumping with severe somatic injuries (mean age: 25.6 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic efficacy of radon baths in patients with osteochondrosis, comparing its effects to balneotherapy using ordinary tap water.
results_summary: The study found that radon baths reduced pain and movement difficulties in patients with osteochondrosis, specifically improving spine mobility but not affecting extremity joints. No significant improvements were observed in the control group using tap water.
population_specificity: 40 patients with osteochondrosis of various spine regions and radicular syndrome, equally divided by gender.
effective_dosage: General baths at 34-36°C, 10-15 minutes, every other day, for a total of 10 sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the short- and long-term effects of spa therapy, including balneotherapy, on pain, functional efficiency, and life satisfaction in patients with osteoarthritis of the spine.
results_summary: Short-term effects showed statistically significant improvement in all outcome measures for both spa and outpatient treatment groups, while long-term effects showed sustained improvement only in the spa group. Spa therapy reduced pain, improved functional efficiency, and increased life satisfaction for at least six months.
population_specificity: Patients with osteoarthritis of the spine (102 in spa therapy, 100 in outpatient treatment, 100 in no therapy).
study_duration: Not specified (assessments at start, one month, and six months post-therapy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the short-term effects of spa rehabilitation (Balneotherapy) on pain, mood, and quality of life in patients with degenerative or post-surgery musculoskeletal disorders (MSDs) under real-life conditions.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in pain, mood, and quality of life after water-based exercise training, either alone or combined with traditional thermal therapies. No statistically significant differences were observed between the two treatment groups, except for a lower reduction in NRSa (activity-related pain) in the group receiving additional thermal therapies. Sulphate water was associated with less improvement compared to other water types.
population_specificity: 123 patients with degenerative (64.3%) or post-surgery (35.8%) MSDs from six Italian spa facilities.
effective_dosage: 12 sessions of water-based exercise (6 sessions/week for 2 weeks); 45 patients also received 12 mud therapy sessions and 12 thermal baths (6 sessions/week for 2 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of adapted physical activity (APA) and patient-oriented therapeutic education (PTE) programs, including aquatic activities (balneotherapy), on clinical signs, symptoms, and quality of life in patients with chronic venous disease (CVD).
results_summary: The study found that APA programs, particularly those including aquatic activities, alleviated clinical signs and symptoms and improved quality of life in CVD patients (stages C0-C5). PTE programs showed benefits for stage C6 patients, though quality of life improvements were rarely assessed. Combining APA and PTE, especially in balneotherapy, yielded promising results.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic venous disease (CVD), classified as stages C0-C6.

study_goal: To develop and validate a method for producing placebo from tap water for medicinal water efficacy trials in Balneotherapy.
results_summary: No significant differences were found between medicinal water and tap water groups in patient identification or opinion changes, indicating the placebo method was effective. Familiarity with the medicinal water did not influence correct identification rates.
population_specificity: 174 patients undergoing Balneotherapy treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and evaluate clinical trials on crenobalneotherapy for low back pain to assess its potential as a treatment.
results_summary: The study reviewed 26 clinical trials involving 2695 patients, finding that some trials had good methodological quality and suggested crenobalneotherapy as a potential treatment for low back pain, though the role of mineral water remains uncertain. The methodological quality of trials needs improvement.
population_specificity: Patients suffering from low back pain treated in spa centers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether immediate spa therapy (Balneotherapy) improves quality of life and alleviates symptoms in adults with plaque psoriasis compared to usual treatments.
results_summary: Immediate spa therapy significantly improved quality of life (DLQI ≤ 10 in 66.1% vs. 41.4% in controls) and reduced pruritus, with persistent benefits observed at 12-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Adults with plaque psoriasis, DLQI > 10, and stable medical treatment for the last 6 months.
effective_dosage: Standardized programs at five French spa resorts (specific dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Immediate spa therapy within 34 days (median), with assessments at 4.5 and 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current knowledge about the effects of Balneotherapy (BT) and identify its possible mechanism of action in rheumatic diseases.
results_summary: Clinical studies confirmed BT's beneficial effects on inflammation, oxidative stress, cartilage metabolism, and immune responses in chronic degenerative musculoskeletal disorders. Preclinical and in vitro studies demonstrated BT's efficacy in reducing pain, inflammation, and oxidative stress markers, as well as its anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and chondroprotective properties.
population_specificity: Patients with rheumatic diseases (e.g., osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis) and murine models of OA and RA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of mud plus bath therapy versus bath therapy alone in treating hand and knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Mud plus balneotherapy showed significant improvements in pain, stiffness, and function for hand osteoarthritis compared to balneotherapy alone. For knee osteoarthritis, differences were less pronounced but numerically favored the mud plus balneotherapy group.
population_specificity: Patients with hand osteoarthritis (52) and knee osteoarthritis (37).
study_duration: 12 months (with evaluations at baseline, week 2, and months 3, 6, 9, and 12)

study_goal: To evaluate the additional effect and safety of peloidotherapy (heated mudpack) combined with usual care versus usual care alone in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) at short- and middle-term follow-up.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant improvement in the Health Assessment Questionnaire (HAQ) scores favoring the peloidotherapy group at all follow-up points. However, the primary outcome (low disease activity) did not show a statistically significant difference between groups at the third month (p=0.15).
population_specificity: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) recruited from the medical ecology and hydroclimatology department of Istanbul Medical Faculty.
effective_dosage: Heated mudpack (41-42°C) applied to painful and active joints 5 days/week for 2 weeks.
study_duration: 2 weeks of intervention, with follow-up assessments at 1 and 3 months post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify new tools for evaluating risk of bias and reporting quality in randomized controlled trials (RCTs) in rehabilitation, including balneotherapy, and to create a matrix of items for reporting and conducting such trials.
results_summary: The study identified 3 new scales (including the SPAC scale for balneotherapy) and the updated Cochrane RoB 2.0 tool, compiling 122 unique items for rehabilitation trials, with variability in items used for reporting and conduct.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus was on rehabilitation trials broadly, not a specific patient group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of peloid therapy combined with home exercise versus home exercise alone in improving pain, function, quality of life, and depression in patients with chronic low back pain.
results_summary: Peloid therapy combined with home exercise showed statistically significant improvements in pain, functional status, and quality of life compared to home exercise alone, both immediately after treatment and one month later. The therapy was particularly effective in reducing pain and improving function in chronic low back pain patients.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic low back pain (cLBP).
effective_dosage: 15 sessions (5 days per week for 3 weeks), each lasting 30 minutes at 45°C.
study_duration: 3 weeks of intervention, with follow-up assessments at 3 weeks and 1 month post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of balneotherapy as a complementary or alternative treatment for psoriasis compared to conventional therapies.
results_summary: The study found that balneotherapy has been proven effective in achieving clinical improvement for psoriasis, with positive outcomes noted in the reviewed literature. It was highlighted as a beneficial complementary treatment alongside other stress management therapies.
population_specificity: Patients with psoriasis (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize scientific evidence on the efficacy of medical hydrology (including balneotherapy) for managing various health conditions.
results_summary: The study found that balneotherapy is beneficial for specific musculoskeletal conditions, with effects lasting up to 9 months, and can support chronic venous insufficiency and inflammatory skin diseases like psoriasis. Higher-quality studies support its integrative use for osteoarthritis, fibromyalgia, and rheumatic low back pain.
population_specificity: Patients with musculoskeletal conditions, chronic venous insufficiency, inflammatory skin diseases, and those in rehabilitation.
study_duration: Effects observed up to 9 months (specific intervention duration not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if hyperthermic baths (HTB) as an add-on treatment could provide fast-acting, clinically relevant improvement in depression severity compared to physical exercise.
results_summary: HTB showed a significant reduction in depression severity (4.3-point improvement in HAM-D score) after 2 weeks compared to physical exercise, with better compliance and no serious adverse events. However, the high dropout rate in the exercise group may have influenced the results.
population_specificity: Medically stable outpatients with moderate depression (HAM-D score ≥ 18).
effective_dosage: Twice weekly HTB sessions (40°C for 15-20 minutes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of balneological outpatient treatment (hydrotherapy and peloidotherapy) on clinical status and serum cytokine levels in patients with chronic low back pain (CLBP).
results_summary: The study group showed significant improvements in pain intensity, disability, and quality of life measures compared to the control group, with benefits sustained for 3 months. The study also noted an increase in anti-inflammatory cytokine IL-10 levels in the treatment group, though no direct correlation with pain scores was established.
population_specificity: 74 patients with chronic low back pain (CLBP).
effective_dosage: Ten sessions (in 2 weeks) of hydrotherapy, peloidotherapy, and home exercise.
study_duration: 2 weeks of intervention, with follow-ups at 1 and 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a stress-prevention program (SGS) that included balneotherapy, along with other interventions, in reducing perceived stress and improving well-being in stressed entrepreneurs from green professions.
results_summary: The study found that the SGS program, which included balneotherapy, significantly improved stress levels and other outcomes immediately after the intervention, with effects remaining stable for at least six months. However, additional telephone-coaching did not further enhance these results.
population_specificity: Entrepreneurs from green professions (mostly full-time farmers) with increased stress levels (mean age: 55.3; 49.1% female).
effective_dosage: Not specified (balneotherapy was part of a multi-component program).
study_duration: 12-day program with follow-up assessments up to 9 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if underwater traction therapy improves chronic low back pain and quality of life.
results_summary: Underwater weight bath traction therapy significantly reduced pain levels (measured by VAS) in patients with chronic low back pain, with sustained improvements during follow-up. No significant changes were observed in disability or quality-of-life metrics beyond pain reduction.
population_specificity: 176 patients with chronic low back pain (lasting >3 months) from outpatient clinics.
effective_dosage: Not specified (therapy involved underwater weight bath traction sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate a new caregiver-reported global severity assessment tool (Comano score) for pediatric atopic eczema (AE) in the context of balneotherapy.
results_summary: The study found a strong correlation between the Comano score and SCORAD (r = 0.74, p < 0.0001), suggesting it may be a promising tool for assessing pediatric AE severity. However, further validation is needed before widespread clinical use.
population_specificity: 867 pediatric patients (ages 1-16 years, mean 5.9 years) with doctor-confirmed atopic eczema undergoing balneotherapy at Comano Thermal Center.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review nonpharmacological interventions, including balneotherapy, to minimize disease consequences in patients with established rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
results_summary: The abstract mentions balneotherapy as one of several nonpharmacological interventions reviewed, but specific results regarding its effects are not detailed. The study highlights the need for such interventions to address unmet needs in RA patients.
population_specificity: Patients with established rheumatoid arthritis (RA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of liman peloid therapy combined with bath and heliotherapy compared to mud-bath therapy with clay peloid and heliotherapy in psoriatic patients.
results_summary: Group 1 (liman peloid, bath, and heliotherapy) showed a significant improvement in delta-PASI, delta-PASI3, and reduced psoriasis recurrences and topical drug use compared to Group 2 (mud-bath therapy with clay peloid and heliotherapy), though PASI reduction was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Psoriatic patients (56 in Group 1, 35 in Group 2)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the clinical effects of head-out immersion in natural thermal mineral water (HINTMW) as a common balneotherapy method for managing hypertension.
results_summary: The study found that HINTMW, either alone or as an adjuvant therapy, had no adverse effects on hypertensive patients and often had positive effects, though more high-quality evidence is needed to confirm therapeutic effectiveness.
population_specificity: Hypertensive patients (total of 1122 participants across 12 randomized controlled trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the scientific evidence on the benefits of aquatic treatments, including balneotherapy, for neck pain.
results_summary: The study found that aquatic treatments reduced neck pain and disability while improving functional capacity, quality of life, joint mobility, balance, relaxation, and mood, with evidence quality ranging from good to weak.
population_specificity: 658 subjects with chronic neck pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the scientific evidence supporting Persian mineral waters (balneotherapy) as a treatment option for psoriasis by reviewing historical medical manuscripts and modern clinical studies.
results_summary: The study found that Persian mineral waters exhibit keratolytic, antiproliferative, antibiotic, anti-inflammatory, and antioxidant effects, which can reduce clinical symptoms of psoriasis and improve patients' quality of life. Historical and modern evidence supports their use in psoriasis treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with psoriasis (no specific demographic details provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the historical ethnopharmacy of peat and Sphagnum moss in Central Europe, focusing on the origins of medical interest in peat in Polish science and the history of Tołpa's peat preparation (TPP).
results_summary: The study found that Tołpa's research ignored historical data on peat's external applications and failed to scientifically confirm internal benefits. TPP's purported anti-cancer properties lacked clinical validation, and the research project ultimately failed pre-clinical and clinical tests.
population_specificity: Not specified (historical and scientific review, not a clinical trial).

study_goal: To compare the efficacy of intermittent versus consecutive balneological outpatient treatment (hydrotherapy and peloidotherapy) in fibromyalgia syndrome (FMS).
results_summary: Pain intensity significantly decreased in both groups, with no significant difference between them. The intermittent group showed a higher proportion of patients achieving minimal clinically important difference (MCID) on the Fibromyalgia Impact Questionnaire (FIQ) at the 1st month (48% vs. 24%), though this difference was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Patients aged 18-60 diagnosed with FMS according to ACR 2010 criteria.
effective_dosage: 20 min of full body immersion in a tap water pool at 38-39°C and 30 min of mud pack application on the back region at 45°C, delivered either five times weekly for 2 weeks (consecutive group) or two times weekly for 5 weeks (intermittent group).
study_duration: 2 weeks for the consecutive group, 5 weeks for the intermittent group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of treatment duration (2 vs. 3 weeks) on the efficacy of spa therapy for pain, functional status, and quality of life in patients undergoing the same treatment protocol.
results_summary: Both therapy durations (2 and 3 weeks) showed significant improvements in pain, physical activity, and quality of life, except for social isolation. The 3-week group demonstrated better pain relief across all measurement times compared to the 2-week group.
population_specificity: Sixty individuals divided into two groups (3-week and 2-week therapy).
effective_dosage: Not specified (same treatment protocol for both groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between daily hot water bathing at home (DHW) and hot water spa bathing (HSPA) with the number of underlying diseases in middle-aged and elderly ambulatory patients.
results_summary: The study found no association between DHW frequency or duration and underlying diseases, but lower HSPA frequency (one to three times per month or twice to five times a year) was significantly associated with increased risk of underlying diseases. The study suggests further research is needed to clarify the relationship between HSPA and patients' mental and physical support.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and elderly ambulatory patients (n=1261, 508 males and 753 females, aged 72.8±6.8 and 73.5±6.9 years, respectively).
effective_dosage: HSPA frequency: at least once a week (reference group), one to three times per month, or twice to five times a year.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of balneological outpatient treatment (hydrotherapy and peloidotherapy) for chronic low back pain.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in pain (VAS), disability (Waddell Index), and quality of life (HAQ) after treatment, with no influence from age, sex, or treatment duration.
population_specificity: 139 patients with chronic low back pain treated at the Department of Medical Ecology and Hydroclimatology (2008-2016).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential efficacy of psammotherapy (hot sand baths) in treating various diseases through a systematic review of existing studies.
results_summary: The review found limited evidence suggesting psammotherapy might improve symptoms and functionality in patients with rheumatoid arthritis and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, but no definitive conclusions on clinical efficacy could be drawn due to the small number of studies.
population_specificity: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the organic fraction of Szigetvár thermal mineral water contributes to its therapeutic effects in patients with osteoarthritis of the hips and knees.
results_summary: The organic fraction significantly improved range of movement (ROM), WOMAC scores, and SF-36 scores compared to tap water, demonstrating beneficial health effects. The mineral water group also showed improvements, but the organic fraction had superior outcomes.
population_specificity: 74 patients (age 67.3 ± 4.48 years) with osteoarthritis of the hips and knees.
study_duration: 3 weeks of treatment, with a 3-month follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of therapeutic muds on the skin microbiome, particularly in relation to rheumatic and dermatologic conditions.
results_summary: Limited data suggest that muds have varying effects on commensal and pathogenic microorganisms of the skin microbiome, but further research is needed to fully characterize these effects and extend their therapeutic indications.
population_specificity: Not specified (studies reviewed likely included individuals with rheumatic or dermatologic conditions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the therapeutic applications of natural medicinal resources, including Balneotherapy, for treating various disorders and its role in disease prevention and rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study highlights that Balneotherapy, using natural medicinal waters, gases, and peloids, is effective for treating gastrointestinal, circulatory, respiratory, bone and joint, and skin disorders, with minimal side effects compared to synthetic drugs. It also notes that combining Balneotherapy with climate therapy under professional supervision can reduce treatment time and improve outcomes.
population_specificity: Not specified (general mention of disorders treated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of inpatient vs outpatient spa therapy on pain, quality of life, and anxiety in elderly patients with generalized osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Both inpatient and outpatient spa therapy were superior to medical treatment (etodolac) in improving pain, quality of life, and anxiety. Inpatient spa therapy showed greater benefits than outpatient therapy in most evaluated parameters.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with generalized osteoarthritis.
study_duration: 2 weeks of treatment, with follow-up at 4 weeks post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of balneotherapy compared to paroxetine in treating generalized anxiety disorder (GAD).
results_summary: The study found that balneotherapy was superior to paroxetine in one quality trial involving 237 participants over 8 weeks, indicating efficacy for GAD. However, safety reporting was poor, and broader evidence for CAM methods in GAD remains limited.
population_specificity: Adults diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) according to standard criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of balneotherapy on chronic low back pain compared to traditional musculoskeletal pain killer treatment.
results_summary: Balneotherapy significantly improved pain levels (at rest and during activity), back pain-specific outcomes (Oswestry questionnaire), and quality of life (EuroQual-5D) in the target group, with effects persisting during follow-up. No significant changes were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: 105 patients suffering from chronic low back pain (52 in the target group, 53 in the control group).
effective_dosage: Thermal mineral water treatment for 15 occasions over 3 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if the clinical benefits of pelotherapy in osteoarthritis patients are mediated by anti-inflammatory effects and neuroendocrine-immune regulation.
results_summary: After a 10-day pelotherapy cycle, patients showed improved knee flexion, reduced pain and stiffness, better physical function, and enhanced quality of life. Serum inflammatory cytokines and eHsp72 decreased, while cortisol levels increased, suggesting systemic anti-inflammatory and neuroendocrine-immune regulatory effects.
population_specificity: 21 patients diagnosed with primary knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (10-day cycle of pelotherapy at a spa center).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze cross-regional variations in the use and access of psoriasis topical therapies, including balneotherapy.
results_summary: The study reported variation in the availability of balneotherapy among psoriasis treatments but did not provide specific efficacy or safety data for balneotherapy.
population_specificity: Dermatologists from the International Psoriasis Council (IPC) across 26 countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evidence supporting conservative therapeutic interventions, including balneotherapy, for treating osteoarthritis in finger joints.
results_summary: The study found that balneotherapy, whether combined or not combined with mud packs and magnetotherapy, was among the effective treatment interventions for individuals with osteoarthritis in finger joints, though evidence quality and effect sizes varied.
population_specificity: Adults aged 55 years and older with hand osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether balneotherapy combined with exercise therapy provides more sustained improvement in joint function and pain reduction compared to exercise therapy alone in patients with hip osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that balneotherapy combined with exercise therapy led to significantly greater improvements in WOMAC pain, stiffness, function, and total scores, as well as EQVAS scores, compared to exercise therapy alone, with 81% of balneotherapy patients achieving Minimal Clinically Important Improvement versus 30% of controls.
population_specificity: Outpatients with hip osteoarthritis according to ACR criteria.
effective_dosage: Balneotherapy administered on 15 occasions over 3 weeks using mineral water with 13.2 mg/L sulfide ion content.
study_duration: 3 weeks of treatment, with follow-up at 12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the therapeutic role of mineral elements and chemical compounds in balneotherapy for musculoskeletal conditions, focusing on double-blind randomized clinical trials.
results_summary: Mineral water or mud treatments showed better and longer improvements in pain, function, quality of life, and clinical parameters for rheumatologic diseases compared to non-mineral treatments, though methodological limitations prevent firm causal conclusions.
population_specificity: Patients with rheumatological and musculoskeletal diseases (knee osteoarthritis, hand osteoarthritis, chronic low back pain, rheumatoid arthritis, osteoporosis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the stress-relieving effects of single moor baths as part of a multimodal stress-reducing prevention program for individuals at risk of burnout.
results_summary: The study found a significant decrease in salivary cortisol after the first moor bath and improved mood state after both baths, suggesting stress-relieving effects. However, the cortisol reduction in week 3 was non-significant.
population_specificity: Subjects with high stress levels and increased risk of developing burnout syndrome (n=78).
effective_dosage: Moor bath (42°C, 20 min) followed by a 20-min resting period, administered seven times over 3 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a 2-week spa therapy (balneotherapy) as an adjunct to usual pharmacological therapy provides beneficial effects in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
results_summary: Spa therapy significantly improved clinical outcomes (pain, global assessments, function, and disease activity) compared to control therapy, with benefits persisting for up to 6 months. The improvements were statistically significant in physician and patient global assessments and disease activity, with trends in pain and swollen joints.
population_specificity: 50 patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) treated with traditional disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs.
effective_dosage: Daily saline balneotherapy session at 36-37°C for 20 minutes (except Sundays).
study_duration: 2 weeks of spa therapy, with follow-up assessments at 3 and 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of consecutive versus intermittent balneological treatments (hydrotherapy and mud pack therapy) on knee osteoarthritis patients without disrupting their daily routines.
results_summary: Both consecutive and intermittent balneological treatments showed statistically significant clinical benefits and improved quality of life in knee osteoarthritis patients, with effects lasting up to 3 months for most parameters, though some variables (e.g., joint stiffness, mental health) showed diminished maintenance over time. Group 1 (consecutive treatment) had more variables where well-being was not maintained post-treatment compared to Group 2 (intermittent treatment).
population_specificity: Fifty patients diagnosed with knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Ten sessions total—Group 1: consecutive sessions over 2 weeks; Group 2: intermittent sessions over 5 weeks. Each session included a 38°C tap water bath followed by a 20-minute 45°C local peloid pack.
study_duration: 2 weeks (Group 1) or 5 weeks (Group 2), with follow-up at 12 weeks post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of a 3-week low-calorie diet and balneological treatment on coagulation parameters in morbidly obese patients to determine if these interventions could mitigate hypercoagulability risks.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in coagulation parameters after the 3-week intervention, suggesting that balneotherapy and a low-calorie diet did not effectively reduce hypercoagulability in morbidly obese patients. The results indicated that substantial fat mass reduction might be necessary before hemostasis improvements occur.
population_specificity: 36 morbidly obese patients (BMI > 40 kg/m2; mean age 46) compared to 24 healthy controls (BMI ≤ 24.9 kg/m2; mean age 39).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether frequent immersion in thermoneutral water (ITW) could improve cardiovascular risk factors such as BMI, waist circumference, blood lipids, fasting blood glucose, and C-reactive protein in patients with mild to moderately elevated blood pressure.
results_summary: The study found no significant reduction in any of the secondary cardiovascular risk factors after 4 and 24 weeks of ITW, with no differences between the intervention and control groups. The authors concluded that ITW was not efficacious in inducing cardiovascular alterations in this hypertensive population.
population_specificity: Patients aged 57.6 ± 9.6 years with mild to moderately elevated blood pressure and a BMI of 29.5 ± 5.7 kg/m².
effective_dosage: 45-60 minutes of immersion in thermal-mineral water at 34.0-36.0 °C, four times a week for 4 weeks (with one group reducing to once a week for an additional 20 weeks).
study_duration: 24 weeks (4 weeks intensive, followed by 20 weeks maintenance for one group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of mud-bath therapy on serum biomarkers and clinical outcomes in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Mud-bath therapy significantly improved pain and function (VAS and WOMAC scores) in knee OA patients. Serum CTX-II levels increased significantly in the mud-bath group, suggesting enhanced cartilage turnover, while other biomarkers (COMP, MPO, hsCRP) remained unchanged.
population_specificity: 103 patients with primary symptomatic bilateral knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: A cycle of mud-bath therapy over 2 weeks (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of hot sulfurous and non-sulfurous water baths in treating knee osteoarthritis, comparing their pain-relieving and functional improvement outcomes.
results_summary: Both sulfurous and non-sulfurous water baths significantly reduced pain and improved physical function in knee osteoarthritis patients, with sulfurous baths showing longer-lasting effects. No significant differences were observed between the two treatment groups immediately post-treatment, but sulfurous baths outperformed non-sulfurous baths at the two-month follow-up.
population_specificity: 140 patients (both genders, mean age 64.8±8.9 years) with knee osteoarthritis and chronic knee pain.
effective_dosage: 30 individual thermal baths (three 20-minute baths per week for 10 weeks) at 37-39 °C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the short-term effects of spa therapy (Balneotherapy) on pain and physical function in older patients (65+ years) with various types of osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in pain, physical function, and global assessments across multiple osteoarthritis subgroups, with responder rates ranging from 50% to 100%. The greatest improvements were observed in generalized and multiple joint osteoarthritis involving the knee.
population_specificity: Patients aged 65+ years with generalized, knee, hip, cervical, or lumbar spine osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Usual therapy packages (specific details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the clinical effects and mechanisms of action of spa therapy (balneotherapy) in treating hand osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that spa therapy had beneficial effects on pain, function, and quality of life in hand osteoarthritis, though additional RCTs are needed to clarify mechanisms and effects of thermal treatments.
population_specificity: Patients with hand osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of mud bath therapy (MBT) and leisure thermal activity (LTA) on endurance time and plasma IL-6 levels following an inspiratory resistive breathing challenge in COPD patients.
results_summary: MBT significantly improved endurance time after the challenge, suggesting a training effect, while LTA did not. Both interventions were safe, with minor adverse events reported in the MBT group.
population_specificity: 42 patients aged 42-76 with mild to severe COPD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the therapeutic efficacy of balneotherapy (mineral waters and peloids) combined with calcipotriol versus calcipotriol alone in treating plaque psoriasis.
results_summary: The study found that balneotherapy combined with calcipotriol resulted in a significantly greater reduction in PASI scores (59.45%) compared to calcipotriol alone (39.34%), with sustained effects observed at 30-day follow-up. The most notable improvement was in desquamation reduction (p < 0.001).
population_specificity: 60 patients with plaque psoriasis, divided into two groups (balneotherapy + calcipotriol vs. calcipotriol alone).
study_duration: 21 days of treatment, with follow-up at 30 days post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the available evidence on the effects of balneotherapy on patients with rheumatoid arthritis, focusing on clinical parameters and functional improvements.
results_summary: The review found statistically significant improvements in several clinical parameters, including functional capacity, morning stiffness, active joints, and handgrip strength, though results on pain were inconclusive. Heterogeneity in methodologies and mineral water compositions limited consistency across studies.
population_specificity: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis (496 participants across 8 RCTs).
study_duration: Follow-up periods ranged from 1 month to 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effectiveness and quality of health resort medicine (HRM) treatments for non-musculoskeletal disorders.
results_summary: HRM treatments showed clinical improvement in skin, respiratory, circulatory, digestive, and nervous system disorders, but evidence was limited by small samples, lack of control groups, and insufficient follow-up.
population_specificity: Patients with non-musculoskeletal disorders from eight countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and evaluate recent evidence on the effectiveness of balneotherapy and spa therapy for patients with chronic low back pain (LBP).
results_summary: The study found that balneotherapy was superior to tap water therapy in relieving pain and improving function in the long term, and spa therapy combining balneotherapy with other treatments was effective in managing LBP, being either superior or equally effective to control treatments in both short and long terms. However, the overall quality of the trials was generally low.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic low back pain (LBP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if adding mud-pack and hot pool treatments (balneotherapy) to patient education improves short- and mild-term outcomes in fibromyalgia patients compared to education alone.
results_summary: Balneotherapy significantly improved patient and physician global assessments, FIQ scores, and subscales (pain, fatigue, stiffness, etc.) post-treatment and at one-month follow-up, but no difference was found in BDI scores. The study concluded that balneotherapy combined with education is more beneficial than education alone for fibromyalgia.
population_specificity: 70 women with fibromyalgia syndrome (60 completed the study).
effective_dosage: Heated pool treatment at 38°C for 20 min/day, followed by mud-pack at 45°C on the back region, applied on weekdays.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the clinical effects and mechanisms of action of spa therapy (balneotherapy and mud-pack therapy) in knee osteoarthritis (OA).
results_summary: The study found that spa therapy has a beneficial effect on pain, function, and quality of life in knee OA, with effects lasting up to 6-9 months post-treatment. The mechanisms are not fully understood but likely involve mechanical, thermal, and chemical factors.
population_specificity: Patients with symptomatic knee osteoarthritis, primarily aged 50 years and over.
study_duration: Effects observed until 6-9 months after treatment (exact intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combined low-dose radon hyperthermia balneo treatment (LDRnHBT) and exercise impacts bone metabolism and quality of life in an at-risk population for osteoporosis.
results_summary: The study found significant changes in bone metabolism markers and self-assessed health in both LDRnHBT and placebo groups, but no significant difference between them. A slight trend favoring LDRnHBT was observed in reducing osteoclast-stimulating protein after 6 months.
population_specificity: Adults in an age group at risk for developing osteoporosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the length of psoriasis remission in patients treated with standard therapeutic modalities, balneotherapy, or a combination of both.
results_summary: The study found that combined therapy (standard treatments and balneotherapy) resulted in a statistically significant longer remission compared to either treatment alone. Balneotherapy alone showed similar remission duration to standard treatments.
population_specificity: 60 adult patients of both sexes with various clinical forms of psoriasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of balneotherapy (BT) and hydrotherapy (HT) in managing fibromyalgia syndrome (FMS).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found moderate-to-strong evidence for small reductions in pain and improvements in health-related quality of life (HRQOL) with HT, but no significant effects on depressive symptoms or tender point count (TPC).
population_specificity: Patients with fibromyalgia syndrome (FMS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the quality of study reports on spa therapy and balneotherapy using the SPAC checklist and examine the relationship between SPAC scores and publication characteristics.
results_summary: The study found that 78% of the analyzed trials focused on musculoskeletal and connective tissue diseases, with an average SPAC score of 10.8 out of 19. Key reporting deficiencies included details on spa facility locations, pH, bathtub scale, additional facilities, care provider qualifications, daily life instructions, and adherence. No correlation was found between SPAC scores and publication period, language, or impact factor.
population_specificity: Patients with diseases of the musculoskeletal system and connective tissue (majority of studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the stress-relieving effects of balneotherapy with progressive muscle relaxation (PMR) and resting, focusing on subjective relaxation and salivary cortisol levels, and to assess if stress levels influenced relaxation responses.
results_summary: Balneotherapy was found to be more beneficial than PMR and resting in terms of subjective relaxation, while all three interventions similarly reduced salivary cortisol levels. Participants with high and low stress levels showed similar relaxation responses despite differences in somatic symptoms and morning cortisol levels.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers (65.3% female).

study_goal: To determine if spa therapy combined with home exercises provides additional benefits over home exercises and usual treatment alone for generalized osteoarthritis associated with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Spa therapy combined with home exercises showed a statistically significant improvement in achieving minimal clinically important improvement (MCII) compared to home exercises alone, but no difference was observed for the patient acceptable symptom state (PASS).
population_specificity: Patients with generalized osteoarthritis associated with knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of balneotherapy plus physical therapy versus physical therapy alone in treating chronic low back pain.
results_summary: The study found that balneotherapy combined with physical therapy led to superior improvements in pain, functionality, and quality of life compared to physical therapy alone. Both groups showed improvements, but the combined treatment group had better outcomes.
population_specificity: 81 patients with chronic low back pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Lake Hévíz thermal mineral water therapy on pain, knee function, and quality of life in patients with knee osteoarthritis compared to a control group using tap water.
results_summary: Balneotherapy significantly improved pain, active flexion degree, physical function (WOMAC), and quality of life (EQ-5D) compared to the control group, with effects persisting for 15 weeks.
population_specificity: 77 outpatients aged 45-75 with mild to moderate knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: 30-minute therapy sessions, five times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether balneotherapy, when added to physiotherapy, improves clinical parameters and quality of life in patients with chronic shoulder pain compared to physiotherapy alone.
results_summary: Balneotherapy combined with physiotherapy showed greater improvement in pain, function, and some quality-of-life measures compared to physiotherapy alone, with significant differences in certain parameters (e.g., VAS on movement, SPADI function score). However, not all improvements were statistically significant.
population_specificity: 46 patients with chronic shoulder pain

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the effects of balneotherapy and mud-bath therapy on pain, symptoms, and quality of life in patients with primary fibromyalgia, using rheumatological, psychiatric, biochemical, and proteomic approaches.
results_summary: Both balneotherapy and mud-bath therapy reduced pain and improved quality of life, with mud-bath therapy showing longer-lasting effects. Significant decreases in BDNF levels were observed after both treatments, but no changes in oxytocin, ATP, or serotonin transporter levels were detected.
population_specificity: 41 patients (39 females, 2 males) with primary fibromyalgia meeting American College of Rheumatology criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of two regimens combining geothermal seawater bathing with NB-UVB therapy versus NB-UVB monotherapy in treating psoriasis.
results_summary: Both combined regimens (three times weekly and intensive daily) showed significantly higher PASI 75 and PASI 90 response rates compared to NB-UVB monotherapy, along with improved quality of life, histological scores, and reduced NB-UVB doses.
population_specificity: 68 psoriasis patients
effective_dosage: Three times weekly or daily geothermal seawater baths combined with NB-UVB therapy

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of spa therapy (balneotherapy) for patients with advanced chronic venous disorders (CVDs) in reducing leg ulcers and improving clinical status, symptoms, and quality of life.
results_summary: The study found no significant reduction in leg ulcer incidence after spa therapy, but it demonstrated significant improvements in clinical severity, symptoms, and quality of life for patients with advanced venous insufficiency, lasting at least one year.
population_specificity: Patients with primary or post-thrombotic chronic venous disorders (CVDs) in CEAP clinical classes C4a, C4b, or C5 (skin changes but no active ulcer).
effective_dosage: Four balneotherapy sessions per day for 6 days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the role of PRM physicians in managing soft tissue pain syndromes, including the efficacy of Balneotherapy for fibromyalgia syndrome (FMS).
results_summary: The study found that Balneotherapy is efficacious in improving symptoms in FMS, alongside other interventions like exercise and cognitive behavioral therapy. It was grouped with meditative movement therapies and acupuncture as effective treatments.
population_specificity: Patients with fibromyalgia syndrome (FMS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of acupuncture and other physical treatments, including balneotherapy, for alleviating pain in knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Balneotherapy was found to produce a statistically significant reduction in pain compared to standard care, though the overall evidence quality was poor, with high risk of bias. In a sensitivity analysis of higher-quality studies, balneotherapy was not specifically highlighted, suggesting uncertainty about its efficacy relative to other treatments.
population_specificity: Patients with osteoarthritis of the knee.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to define the role of PRM physicians in managing inflammatory arthritis, including the use of balneotherapy as a non-pharmacological intervention.
results_summary: The abstract highlights balneotherapy as one of the non-pharmacological treatments used by PRM physicians to manage inflammatory arthritis, though specific efficacy data for balneotherapy alone are not detailed. Therapeutic patient education and exercise are emphasized as the cornerstones of therapy with strong evidence, while physical modalities like balneotherapy are primarily used to decrease pain and stiffness.
population_specificity: People with inflammatory arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether balneotherapy with mineral waters and mineral-water containing mud is effective in managing fibromyalgia symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that balneotherapy could improve fibromyalgia symptoms, including pain, depression, and minor symptoms, based on a systematic review of 7 selected studies.
population_specificity: Patients with fibromyalgia (142 received balneotherapy, 129 were controls).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to estimate the effect of lifestyle adjustment activities, including balneotherapy, on patients with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: Of the 63 patients followed, 76.2% no longer met the criteria for metabolic syndrome after a median follow-up of 10.4 months. The study suggests that lifestyle interventions in a spa environment may help a significant proportion of patients achieve remission from metabolic syndrome.
population_specificity: Adults with metabolic syndrome (≥3 NCEP-ATPIII criteria), predominantly female (76.2%), mean age 61.2 years.
study_duration: 3-week standard stay in the spa, with 12-month follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and meta-analyze clinical trials on the effects of Hungarian thermal mineral water balneotherapy for conditions like chronic low back pain, osteoarthritis, and chronic pelvic inflammatory disease.
results_summary: The meta-analysis confirmed balneotherapy's beneficial effects on pain in degenerative joint and spinal diseases, as well as chronic pelvic inflammatory disease. It also showed positive impacts on antioxidant status, metabolic, and inflammatory parameters.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic low back pain, knee osteoarthritis, hand osteoarthritis, and chronic pelvic inflammatory disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of sulphurous water balneotherapy in alleviating symptoms of hand osteoarthritis compared to warm tap water.
results_summary: The study found that balneotherapy with sulphurous water significantly improved pain, grip strength, and quality of life immediately post-treatment, with sustained benefits in pain and functional indices at 3 and 6 months. However, improvements in morning stiffness and quality of life were not sustained long-term.
population_specificity: 47 patients with hand osteoarthritis meeting ACR criteria.
study_duration: 3 weeks of treatment, with follow-ups at 3 and 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of balneotherapy as a non-pharmacological intervention for fibromyalgia syndrome (FMS) compared to control interventions.
results_summary: The study found that balneotherapy showed small to moderate benefits over placebo in medium-sized trials, though evidence was limited due to methodological quality issues and heterogeneity. It was less effective than multicomponent therapy and aerobic exercise but more effective than some pharmacological treatments.
population_specificity: Patients with fibromyalgia syndrome (FMS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects and safety of Dead Sea treatments, including balneotherapy, for rheumatologic diseases and psoriasis.
results_summary: Dead Sea treatments were found effective for psoriasis and several rheumatologic diseases, with no significant increase in skin neoplasia or blood pressure issues, though skin actinic damage was noted. Ingestion of Dead Sea water was toxic in rare cases.
population_specificity: Patients with rheumatologic diseases (rheumatoid arthritis, psoriatic arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, knee osteoarthritis) and psoriasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the beneficial effects of balneotherapy on cardiac function and inflammatory status in patients with chronic heart failure (CHF).
results_summary: Balneotherapy significantly improved clinical symptoms, cardiac function (EF, CTR), and reduced inflammatory biomarkers (hsCRP, TNF-α, IL-6) in CHF patients. The improvement in BNP correlated with reduced inflammation.
population_specificity: Thirty-two patients with systolic CHF (NYHA functional status II or III).
effective_dosage: Immersion in a hot spring at 40°C for 10 min daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of thermal mineral water (balneotherapy) combined with magnetotherapy versus magnetotherapy alone in treating hand osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Balneotherapy combined with magnetotherapy showed statistically significant improvements in pain, hand function, and quality of life compared to the control group, with sustained benefits observed in the 38°C thermal water group.
population_specificity: Patients aged 50-70 with hand osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Thermal mineral water baths at 36°C or 38°C for 20 minutes daily, five times a week, plus magnetotherapy three times weekly.
study_duration: Three weeks of intervention with follow-up at 13 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of balneotherapy alongside other rehabilitation methods in improving clinical outcomes for patients with shoulder stiffness.
results_summary: Balneotherapy, combined with physical therapy, showed positive effects on clinical progression, contrasting with classic rehabilitation exercises which initially had negative effects. The study did not detail specific outcomes solely for balneotherapy.
population_specificity: Patients with shoulder stiffness (148 cases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of balneotherapy versus physical therapy, both combined with exercise, in patients with chronic low back pain.
results_summary: Both treatment groups showed significant improvements, but the balneotherapy group demonstrated better outcomes in back extensor muscle strength, flexibility, disability index, and certain quality-of-life measures. Balneotherapy combined with exercise was superior to physical therapy plus exercise in improving quality of life and flexibility.
population_specificity: Sixty patients with chronic low back pain.
study_duration: Duration of intervention not explicitly stated, but follow-up was at 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of balneotherapy in patients with chronic low back pain compared to conventional physiotherapy alone.
results_summary: The study found that balneotherapy combined with physiotherapy significantly improved pain intensity, functional disability, and spinal mobility compared to physiotherapy alone, with statistically superior outcomes in Group 1.
population_specificity: 60 patients with lumbar spondylosis (chronic low back pain).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether balneotherapy with thermal-mineral water improves clinical parameters and quality of life in patients with chronic low back pain compared to tap water.
results_summary: The study found that balneotherapy significantly improved lumbar spine mobility, pain scores (VAS), Oswestry index, EuroQoL-5D index, and most SF-36 parameters compared to baseline. The treatment group showed better outcomes than the control group using tap water.
population_specificity: 60 patients with chronic low back pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate changes in antioxidant, inflammatory, and metabolic parameters in obese and hypertensive patients during balneotherapy and assess its safety.
results_summary: Balneotherapy showed transient improvements in some metabolic and inflammatory markers (e.g., C-reactive protein, hemoglobin A1c) in hypertensive and obese patients, but effects were not sustained after 3 months. The study concluded that balneotherapy is safe and not contraindicated for these populations.
population_specificity: Obese (n=22) and hypertensive (n=20) patients, with matched controls.
effective_dosage: 15 sessions of 30 minutes each in thermal water at 38°C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of balneotherapy in managing fibromyalgia symptoms compared to standard pharmacological treatment.
results_summary: Balneotherapy showed superior improvements in pain intensity, Fibromyalgia Impact Questionnaire (FIQ), Beck Depression Inventory (BDI), patient and investigator global assessments, and tender point count compared to the control group, with benefits lasting up to three months for most measures. Significant improvements were also noted in certain SF-36 subscales (PF, GH, MH) in the balneotherapy group, while the control group showed no such improvements.
population_specificity: Fifty women with fibromyalgia under pharmacological treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether balneotherapy with mineral sulphate-bicarbonate-calcium water could improve symptoms and quality of life in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Balneotherapy significantly improved pain, functional capacities, and quality of life, with effects persisting through follow-up. Symptomatic drug consumption was also reduced, and tolerability was good with only light, transitory side effects.
population_specificity: 60 outpatients with primary bilateral knee osteoarthritis (ACR criteria).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of balneotherapy (BT) in improving respiratory and other symptoms in patients with Primary Fibromyalgia Syndrome (FMS) when combined with standard physical therapy modalities (PTM).
results_summary: The study found that PTM combined with BT (PTM+BT) led to significant improvements in dyspnea, spirometric measurements, pain, depressive symptoms, and quality of life, with sustained benefits at 6-month follow-up compared to PTM alone or PTM with hydrotherapy (PTM+HT).
population_specificity: 56 patients with Primary Fibromyalgia Syndrome (FMS), matched by age, gender, and illness duration.
study_duration: 3 weeks of therapy, with follow-up at 6 months post-therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential use of CO(2) balneotherapy as an adjuvant therapeutic option for cardiovascular diseases by reviewing existing evidence.
results_summary: The study identified three main effects of CO(2) hydrotherapy: reduced core temperature, increased cutaneous blood flow, and improved thermal sensation. It also discussed indications and contraindications but highlighted the need for further methodologically robust studies.
population_specificity: Patients with cardiovascular diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review historical and contemporary evidence for the medicinal uses of water, including balneotherapy, and explore factors contributing to its decline in some regions.
results_summary: The study highlights the long-standing use of water therapies (hydrotherapy, balneotherapy, thalassotherapy) across ancient societies and their continued use today, though diminished in Anglo-Saxon regions due to lack of research funding and the rise of allopathic medicine. Modern science has identified health-giving properties in water, but the abstract does not detail specific outcomes of balneotherapy.
population_specificity: Not specified (historical and contemporary general use)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to address the lack of international recognition and standardization in Health Resort Medicine, Balneology, Medical Hydrology, and Climatology by proposing a structured framework and terminology.
results_summary: The study highlights the need for standardized definitions and international consensus in the field, emphasizing the role of balneotherapy, hydrotherapy, and climatotherapy in health promotion, prevention, treatment, and rehabilitation. It suggests integrating these therapies within the ICF framework to account for environmental and social factors.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion, no specific population studied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of balneotherapy at Comano spa versus topical corticosteroids in treating mild to moderate atopic dermatitis in children.
results_summary: Balneotherapy and topical corticosteroids both significantly reduced AD severity and improved quality of life after 2 weeks, though corticosteroids were more effective in reducing SCORAD scores. At 4 months, balneotherapy showed fewer and shorter relapses compared to corticosteroids.
population_specificity: Children aged 1-14 years with mild to moderate atopic dermatitis.
study_duration: 2 weeks of intervention, with follow-up at 4 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of balneotherapy (BT) compared to paroxetine in treating generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) over an 8-week period.
results_summary: BT showed significant improvement in HAM-A scores compared to paroxetine (-12.0 vs -8.7; p<0.001), with higher remission (19% vs 7%) and sustained response rates (51% vs 28%). The study concluded BT is an effective and well-tolerated treatment for GAD.
population_specificity: Outpatients meeting DSM-IV criteria for generalized anxiety disorder (GAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of balneotherapy on gait properties and clinical health parameters in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Balneotherapy improved gait speed, stance time, cadence, and stride length, while significantly reducing pain (VAS), Lequesne index, WOMAC score, and global assessments. The treatment showed statistically significant positive effects on both gait and clinical outcomes.
population_specificity: 30 patients with knee osteoarthritis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the chemical composition and health benefits of Barberry (Berberis vulgaris L.) and its potential use in functional foods.
results_summary: The study found that Barberry contains phenolic compounds, antioxidants, and vitamins, contributing to its medicinal properties and potential for functional food applications. Clinical trials and epidemiological studies supported its health benefits.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human health focus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current literature on Banaba Leaf and its constituents, focusing on its hypoglycemic effects and other potential health benefits.
results_summary: Banaba Leaf extracts, particularly corosolic acid and ellagitannins, demonstrated significant hypoglycemic effects, improved lipid metabolism, and exhibited additional beneficial activities such as antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and antineoplastic effects. No adverse effects were reported in animal studies or human clinical trials.
population_specificity: Animal models, human subjects, and in vitro systems.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review pharmacokinetic parameters of berberine (from Barberry), including bioavailability, metabolism, distribution, excretion, and drug-drug interactions, as well as evaluate developed products with improved bioavailability.
results_summary: Berberine exhibits multiple pharmacological effects but has poor bioavailability (<1%). It undergoes extensive metabolism, with fecal excretion being higher than urinary or biliary excretion. Concomitant administration with certain drugs may lead to significant interactions.
population_specificity: Animal and human studies (not specified further).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of barberry and its primary component berberine on key human CYP450 enzymes, particularly focusing on potential drug interactions.
results_summary: The study found that berberine influences multiple CYP450 isoforms, including CYP3A4/5, CYP2D6, CYP2C9, CYP2E1, CYP1A1/2, and most CYP2B subfamily isoforms, potentially affecting drug metabolism and toxicity. The most significant interactions were related to its inhibitory effects on CYP2D6 and CYP3A4, which are crucial for metabolizing many clinically used drugs.
population_specificity: Not specified (human CYP450 enzymes studied, but no specific human population mentioned).
interactions: Inhibitory effects on CYP2D6 and CYP3A4, potentially affecting drug metabolism.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether berberine, derived from Barberry, can enhance the functionality of HDL particles and improve cholesterol metabolism.
results_summary: The study concluded that berberine may regulate markers of HDL activity, such as apo-AI, cholesterol efflux, LCAT, PON1, and S1P, potentially improving dysfunctional HDL and serving as a therapeutic agent for cardiovascular conditions. However, further human trials are needed to confirm these effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review, not a clinical trial)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of purple-black barberry on plasma lipids and inflammatory biomarkers in subjects with cardiovascular risk factors.
results_summary: Barberry consumption significantly reduced plasma levels of TG, TC, LDL-C, sd-LDL-C, non-HDL-C, TC/HDL-C, and CRP compared to placebo, indicating improved lipid profile and reduced inflammation.
population_specificity: Subjects with cardiovascular risk factors (mean age 54.06 ± 10.19 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether bitter phytochemicals in Barberry and other herbs could modulate GLP-1 secretion and metabolic regulation via bitter taste receptors.
results_summary: The study suggests that Barberry, as a berberine-containing herb, may stimulate GLP-1 secretion and offer metabolic benefits, including improved glucose and lipid homeostasis, through activation of bitter taste receptors.
population_specificity: Metabolic syndrome individuals or diabetic patients with dyslipidemia-related comorbidities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the botany, traditional uses, phytochemistry, and pharmacology of Berberis spp. (Barberry) as described in Islamic traditional medicine.
results_summary: The study found that Berberis species have been traditionally used for skin, liver, stomach, kidney, and eye problems, with pharmacological studies supporting these uses, primarily due to isoquinoline alkaloids. However, clinical studies are needed to confirm therapeutic effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (traditional and pharmacological studies referenced).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature on the effects of Barberry (Berberis vulgaris) and its isolated alkaloids, particularly berberine, in managing diabetes and related complications.
results_summary: The study found that Barberry and its alkaloids, such as berberine, demonstrated efficacy in improving blood glucose levels in both animal models and human clinical trials, mediated through various signaling pathways like α-glucosidase inhibition and insulin sensitivity modulation.
population_specificity: Animal models and human subjects (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate berberine's effect on blood pressure and cardiovascular disease risk, providing guidance for clinicians and highlighting research gaps.
results_summary: The evidence on berberine's effect on blood pressure was limited, of low quality, and inconclusive. Some studies showed moderate reductions in blood pressure, but effects could not be reliably attributed to berberine alone due to heterogeneity and mixed results.
population_specificity: 614 participants across five randomised controlled trials and two non-randomised controlled trials, with varied diagnoses and settings.
study_duration: Varied across studies (not specified in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of chronic consumption of berries, including barberry, on cardiovascular disease risk factors such as blood pressure, endothelial function, and inflammatory biomarkers.
results_summary: Barberry juice, among other berries, significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure. However, subgroup analysis showed these associations were limited to cranberry and cherry juice, not barberry specifically.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population with cardiovascular risk factors implied)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the efficacy and safety of berberine (found in Barberry) for treating dyslipidemia, with consideration of potential sex-specific effects.
results_summary: Berberine modestly reduced LDL cholesterol, total cholesterol, triglycerides, and apolipoprotein B while increasing HDL cholesterol, with greater HDL benefits in women. Short-term use appeared safe, with no serious adverse events reported, though mild gastrointestinal effects were noted.
population_specificity: Adults with dyslipidemia, primarily from mainland China and Hong Kong.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and meta-analyze the effects of berberine and barberry on anthropometric measures (BMI, BW, WC, WHR) in adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant change in BMI or BW but noted a significant reduction in WHR following berberine consumption. Further high-quality trials were recommended to confirm these findings.
population_specificity: Adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of Barberry on anthropometric indices and metabolic profile in patients with Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA).
results_summary: Barberry extract significantly reduced body fat percent, LDL-C, and systolic blood pressure, while also improving waist and hip circumference, FBS, and HDL-C compared to placebo. Weight and BMI increased in both groups but were significant only in the placebo group.
population_specificity: 70 active RA patients (62 completed the study).
effective_dosage: 6 capsules of 500 mg barberry extract daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the functional compounds and nutraceutical features of barberry species and their potential health benefits.
results_summary: The study found that barberry contains compounds like berberine, anthocyanins, and flavonoids, which have pain-relieving, antimicrobial, and antioxidant properties, and may help reduce cholesterol, blood glucose, and prevent diseases like Alzheimer's. Barberry derivatives are also considered useful additives in various industries, particularly food.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human health context)

study_goal: The abstract does not specify a study goal regarding Barberry.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide study results regarding Barberry's effects.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to update the pharmacological effects of Berberis vulgaris and its active constituent, berberine, by reviewing studies from 2008 to 2015.
results_summary: The study found that berberine and B. vulgaris have diverse pharmacological effects, including potential benefits for treating tumor, diabetes, cardiovascular disease, hyperlipidemia, inflammation, infections, and neurological conditions. Over 1200 articles were reviewed, indicating broad therapeutic applications.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral aqueous extract of dried barberry could effectively and safely reduce acne vulgaris in adolescents.
results_summary: The study found that barberry extract significantly reduced noninflamed, inflamed, and total acne lesions, as well as acne severity scores, by approximately 44% after 4 weeks, with no notable side effects reported.
population_specificity: Adolescents aged 12-17 years with moderate to severe acne vulgaris.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of barberry supplementation on plasma lipid concentration in adults through a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Barberry supplementation significantly reduced total cholesterol, triglycerides, and LDL cholesterol levels, but did not significantly affect HDL cholesterol levels. The study concluded that barberry is effective for improving lipid parameters, though further large-scale studies are needed.
population_specificity: Adult population

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of barberry supplementation on glycemic indices, including fasting blood sugar, insulin levels, HOMA-IR, and HbA1c, in adults.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that barberry significantly reduced insulin levels but did not significantly affect other glycemic indices. The study concluded that more high-quality RCTs are needed to clarify barberry's effects on blood glucose control, especially in diabetic patients.
population_specificity: Adults (452 participants across 7 studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of genetic factors on weight loss outcomes following bariatric surgery and GLP1-RA treatment.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery patients experienced a -21.17% weight change between 6 and 48 months, with a modest link between higher BMI polygenic scores and lower weight loss. The study found no significant genetic associations affecting GLP1-RA effectiveness but confirmed treatment efficacy across ancestry groups.
population_specificity: 10,960 individuals from 9 multiancestry biobank studies across 6 countries.
