study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the diagnosis and management strategies for gastrocolic fistula (GCF), a rare but serious complication following metabolic bariatric surgery (MBS).
results_summary: GCF was most prevalent after laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG), with surgical intervention (exploratory laparoscopy) proving effective in most cases. Diagnostic tools like CT scans were commonly used, but non-surgical treatments (OTSC, stents) showed inconsistent efficacy.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent metabolic bariatric surgery (primarily LSG) and developed GCF.
study_duration: Varied (acute cases: 14-61 days; chronic cases: 1-12 months)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate changes in gut microbiota composition before and after bariatric surgery and their association with clinical outcomes like weight loss, insulin sensitivity, and lipid metabolism.
results_summary: Post-surgery, patients showed increased microbial diversity, reduced Firmicutes, and elevated beneficial bacteria, correlating with improvements in weight loss, insulin sensitivity, and lipid profiles, though some studies reported inconsistent changes.
population_specificity: Obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery (Roux-en-Y gastric bypass or sleeve gastrectomy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the prevalence and correlates of food addiction (FA) at 5 and 10 years following metabolic and bariatric surgery (MBS), and its association with weight loss and psychological functioning.
results_summary: The prevalence of FA decreased from 12.9% at 5 years to 8.4% at 10 years post-MBS. Higher FA symptoms were associated with poorer weight loss (%TWL) and lower psychological functioning at both follow-up points, with 3% of cases being new-onset FA at 10 years.
population_specificity: 173 participants (73% women, 93.6% Roux-en-Y gastric bypass) from the Oslo Bariatric Surgery Study (OBSS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether bariatric surgery outcomes differ among high-risk (C5, C6) and low-risk (C4) clusters of individuals at risk for type 2 diabetes and comorbidities.
results_summary: High-risk clusters (C5, C6) showed the greatest metabolic improvements, including reduced insulin resistance, improved β-cell function, and higher prediabetes remission rates compared to low-risk cluster C4. Participants from high-risk clusters transitioned to low-risk clusters post-surgery, unlike the control group.
population_specificity: Individuals without type 2 diabetes but at risk for it, defined by elevated BMI, categorized into Tübingen Clusters (C4, C5, C6).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the relationship between eating disorders (EDs) and metabolic and bariatric surgery (MBS), including risks, outcomes, and potential interventions.
results_summary: The study found that while EDs are not an absolute contraindication for MBS, a small subset of patients experience recurrent or emergent ED symptoms post-surgery, leading to poorer outcomes. Psychosocial and neurobiological factors may contribute to these symptoms, and structured postsurgical treatment may be beneficial.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing metabolic and bariatric surgery (MBS) with or without eating disorders (EDs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether preoperative bariatric surgery reduces short-term complications in patients undergoing total joint arthroplasty (TJA).
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery before total hip arthroplasty (THA) was associated with significantly higher odds of complications (11.6% vs. 6.3% in controls), particularly wound-related issues. No significant difference in complications was observed for total knee arthroplasty (TKA) patients.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent bariatric surgery before TJA (199 THA, 479 TKA) matched with controls (644 THA, 1,657 TKA) based on BMI, age, sex, joint replaced, and ASA class.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of bariatric surgery on reproductive and metabolic outcomes in obese women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).
results_summary: Bariatric surgery significantly improved metabolic parameters by 3 months post-surgery, with sustained improvements in ovulation and luteinizing hormone levels, but limited effects on testosterone, ovarian morphology, and anti-Müllerian hormone. Despite substantial weight loss, further reductions did not proportionally enhance outcomes.
population_specificity: Obese women with PCOS (n=192).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare postoperative functional and surgical outcomes of open carpal tunnel release (CTR) in patients with or without a history of bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Patients with a history of bariatric surgery showed a tendency for greater benefit from open CTR compared to controls, though this was not statistically significant. Minor complication rates and postoperative functional scores were similar between groups.
population_specificity: Adult patients who underwent open CTR, with or without a history of bariatric surgery, matched by age, sex, race, BMI, and comorbidities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate an educational intervention based on the Health Action Process Approach to improve dietary and physical activity outcomes in patients who underwent bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The intervention improved self-efficacy, action planning, and behavioral intention related to diet and physical activity self-management, along with significant improvements in iron blood test results.
population_specificity: 100 patients who had undergone bariatric surgery in Tehran, Iran, within the past year.
study_duration: 2 months of educational intervention, with follow-up measurements at 4 months post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare clinical and neurophysiological features of Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) cases linked to diet-induced weight loss versus those associated with bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that rapid weight loss, whether from dieting or bariatric surgery, may trigger GBS, with all five diet-induced cases showing axonal damage and full recovery within 6 months. The rate of weight loss exceeded safe guidelines, suggesting a potential link to GBS onset.
population_specificity: Five patients with diet-induced GBS and a literature review of 19 bariatric surgery-associated GBS cases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy and safety of 12 months of GLP1-RA treatment (liraglutide or semaglutide) in patients with weight regain after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: After 12 months of GLP1-RA treatment, patients experienced significant reductions in total body weight, BMI, and percentage excess body weight, with semaglutide showing greater efficacy than liraglutide. Adverse events were mild and transient, reported in 32.5% of patients.
population_specificity: Patients with weight regain after bariatric surgery (80% female).
effective_dosage: Liraglutide (3.0 mg daily subcutaneous injection) or semaglutide (1.0 mg weekly subcutaneous injection).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to consolidate existing reviews on the effects of pre- and post-operative exercise training on health outcomes in metabolic and bariatric surgery programs.
results_summary: The study found that preoperative exercise may positively affect BMI and 6-minute walking test distance, while postoperative exercise may improve body weight, BMI, waist circumference, bone mineral density, 6-minute walking test distance, muscle strength, and systolic blood pressure. However, definitive conclusions remain elusive due to methodological limitations.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing metabolic and bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and outcomes of metabolic and bariatric surgery (MBS) in patients with ventricular assist devices (VADs).
results_summary: The study found that MBS in VAD patients had a low 30-day mortality rate (0.8%) and no major adverse events like pulmonary embolism or stroke, though VAD patients had a slightly increased risk of prolonged hospital stays and blood transfusions compared to matched counterparts.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity and heart failure managed with ventricular assist devices (VADs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the main nutritional complications associated with bariatric surgery (BS) based on their center's experience as a national reference in the field.
results_summary: The study highlights that BS has favorable outcomes in weight loss and resolution of obesity-related comorbidities but can lead to complications such as protein-calorie malnutrition and micronutrient deficiencies due to dietary and physiological changes. Non-specialist physicians need awareness of these issues for timely diagnosis and treatment.
population_specificity: Individuals undergoing bariatric surgery (general obesity population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to adapt and evaluate the Spanish version of the EBBS questionnaire for assessing adherence to post-bariatric surgery lifestyle recommendations and its association with long-term weight outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that 70% of participants experienced significant weight regain, with emotional eating (65%) and depression (53%) being common. Higher EBBS scores were significantly associated with greater excess weight loss, particularly for patients maintaining over 50% EWL, indicating the tool's predictive value for weight regain risk.
population_specificity: 100 patients who underwent sleeve gastrectomy (mean follow-up 90.4 ± 46 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy, indications, outcomes, and long-term considerations of bariatric surgery, comparing current surgical procedures and alternative weight-loss treatments.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery achieves significant initial weight loss (30% TWL) with sustained long-term outcomes, similar TWL rates between SG and RYGB at five years (23.7% vs 27.2%), low complication rates (1.5-4.8%), and significant improvement or resolution of comorbidities, particularly diabetes.
population_specificity: People with obesity in Australia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of bariatric surgery on outcomes and cost-effectiveness among patients with obesity, particularly those with cirrhosis.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was associated with improved survival (9.67 vs. 9.46 years overall; 9.09 vs. 8.23 years in cirrhosis) and was cost-effective, especially for patients with cirrhosis at a willingness-to-pay threshold of $100,000 per quality-adjusted life-year.
population_specificity: US veterans older than 18 years with a BMI >35 or BMI >30 with major metabolic comorbidities, including a subset with cirrhosis.
study_duration: Data analyzed from September 2008 to September 2023 (follow-up up to 15 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify factors related to insufficient weight loss (IWL) following bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that 8% of cases experienced IWL, with significant differences in body composition changes between sufficient weight loss (SWL) and IWL groups. Predictors of IWL included older age, higher baseline BMI, diabetes mellitus, non-smoking, and sleeve gastrectomy.
population_specificity: 3456 individuals who underwent bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the prevalence and correlates of eating disorders in pre-bariatric surgery patients to identify those needing psychological support.
results_summary: The study found a high prevalence (65.8%) of eating disorder risk among pre-bariatric surgery patients, with higher risk associated with Class II obesity, younger age, and concurrent depression. These findings suggest prioritizing psychological assessment for this patient profile to improve surgical outcomes.
population_specificity: 275 pre-bariatric surgery patients (mean age 38.5 years, mean BMI 42.3 kg/m², 62.5% female) from the BariPredict cohort.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a multidisciplinary team approach in managing super-super obesity through pre-operative optimization and sleeve gastrectomy.
results_summary: The patient achieved significant pre-operative weight loss, improved mobility, and a 37% excess weight loss over one year, reducing BMI from 106.25 to 66.79 kg/m². The study highlights the MDT approach as effective for substantial weight loss and health improvement in super-super obesity.
population_specificity: A 49-year-old male with super-super obesity (BMI 106.25 kg/m²) and comorbidities including type 2 diabetes and obstructive sleep apnea.

study_goal: To explore the long-term patient experiences and perspectives of adolescents who underwent metabolic and bariatric surgery (MBS) a decade after the procedure.
results_summary: Participants reported significant improvements in daily life, physical, mental, and social health due to weight loss post-MBS. They emphasized the need for better healthcare access, pre-surgery treatment of neuropsychiatric disorders, and ongoing psychosocial support, though many did not attend regular follow-ups.
population_specificity: Adolescents who underwent metabolic and bariatric surgery (MBS).
study_duration: Follow-up conducted a decade after MBS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of bariatric surgery (sleeve gastrectomy) on diabetes remission in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus and morbid obesity.
results_summary: The study found significant weight loss (146.80±25.81 kg to 97.87±17.56 kg) and increased odds of diabetes remission post-surgery, with initial weight and high glycemia as predictors of remission.
population_specificity: 91 patients (50 women, 41 men) aged 23-67 years with type 2 diabetes and morbid obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze gastrointestinal-related complications (GRCs) and their risk factors following bariatric surgery (BS), specifically sleeve gastrectomy (SG) and Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB).
results_summary: Among 323,066 BS patients, 3.79% developed GRCs, with gastrointestinal bleeding, bowel obstruction, and anastomotic issues being the most common. Risk factors included advanced age, anemia, cardiovascular conditions, and liver disease, which had differing effects depending on the surgery type.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent bariatric surgery (SG or RYGB) in the U.S. from 2010 to 2019, as recorded in the Nationwide Inpatient Sample database.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess how rates of discussion and progression to metabolic and bariatric surgery (MBS) varied by race and sex over 20 years.
results_summary: The study found that while discussions about MBS increased over time, Black patients were less likely to progress to surgery than non-Black patients, and men were less likely than women to discuss or receive MBS. Disparities in progression narrowed for race but widened for sex over the study period.
population_specificity: Patients with class 2 obesity or higher from a large tertiary academic health system.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare changes in adipose tissue cell populations and pathways in mice after weight loss induced by vertical sleeve gastrectomy (VSG) or semaglutide treatment, focusing on identifying cells that revert to a lean-like state versus those that persist from obesity.
results_summary: The study found that VSG and semaglutide induced weight loss in mice, with some adipose tissue cell populations returning to a lean-like phenotype while others remained altered from the obese state. The data provided insights into the differences between adipose tissue from lean animals and those that had previously been obese.
population_specificity: Murine (mice) with diet-induced obesity

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the development, implementation, and outcomes of bariatric surgery at the University and Clinical Centre Tuzla over a three-year period.
results_summary: The study found significant weight loss and improvement in comorbid conditions with minimal postoperative complications and no in-hospital mortality, demonstrating progress in treating morbid obesity in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent bariatric surgery at the University and Clinical Centre Tuzla.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare cardiac structure and diastolic function before and after bariatric surgery and examine its association with BMI variation.
results_summary: Significant reverse cardiac remodeling occurred after bariatric surgery, including reductions in left atrial volume index, left ventricular diameters, and LV mass index, but these changes were not associated with BMI reduction. The prevalence of diastolic dysfunction also decreased, though without a clear link to BMI change.
population_specificity: Consecutive bariatric surgery patients without prior bariatric surgery, moderate to severe valvular disease, or lack of follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential role of bariatric surgery in managing chronic pain in patients with failed back surgery syndrome (FBSS) and obesity, emphasizing a multidisciplinary approach.
results_summary: The study reported significant pain score reduction and early improvements in mobility and well-being post-surgery, highlighting bariatric surgery as a potential adjunctive treatment for chronic pain in FBSS patients with obesity.
population_specificity: A 42-year-old woman with FBSS, chronic back pain, narcolepsy, rheumatoid arthritis, and obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the state of bariatric surgery in Poland in 2023, focusing on procedure volumes, regional variations, and the role of KOS-BAR centers.
results_summary: The study found that sleeve gastrectomy (SG) was the dominant procedure (82% of surgeries), with significant regional variations in access. Newer techniques were rarely performed, and over half of surgeries occurred in KOS-BAR centers.
population_specificity: Bariatric surgery centers in Poland affiliated with the Metabolic and Bariatric Surgery Chapter of the Association of Polish Surgeons.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide a comprehensive overview of the complications associated with metabolic and bariatric surgery for gastroenterologists.
results_summary: The study highlights that bariatric surgery is increasingly used to treat obesity and metabolic disorders, with laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy and Roux-en-Y gastric bypass being the most common procedures. However, complications are frequent and can occur long after surgery.
population_specificity: Global population with overweight or obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the success rate of bariatric surgery in treating obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) in obese patients and identify factors influencing its effectiveness.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery had an overall success rate of 61.4% and a cure rate of 52.6% for OSA. Success was more likely in female, younger, and thinner patients, with factors like age below 53 and pre-surgical weight below 105 kg being significant predictors.
population_specificity: Obese patients aged 18-65 years with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of teleconsultation versus face-to-face care for individuals undergoing metabolic and bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Teleconsultation showed comparable outcomes to face-to-face care in adherence rates and postoperative BMI loss, suggesting it may be an equally effective alternative. However, the low level of evidence due to high risk of bias indicates a need for further high-quality studies.
population_specificity: Individuals at any period of metabolic and bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether metabolic and bariatric surgery (MBS) should be considered for weight maintenance in patients who have successfully lost weight but may regain it after discontinuing other obesity treatments.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that MBS could be a potential option for long-term weight maintenance in patients with a history of severe obesity, particularly after gastric band removal or discontinuation of pharmacological treatments, though the need for revisional MBS raises questions about its role in weight maintenance.
population_specificity: Patients with a history of severe obesity who are currently normal weight or overweight and may discontinue other obesity treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of bariatric surgery on the incidence of alcohol use disorder (AUD) and depression during the postoperative period.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in AUD and depression between pre- and post-operative assessments, though a notable reduction in severe depression was observed in patients undergoing sleeve gastrectomy.
population_specificity: 68 patients (85.3% female, average age 42.81±9.28 years) who underwent sleeve gastrectomy or Roux-en-Y gastric bypass.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of bariatric surgery in a morbidly obese adolescent with kidney failure to determine if it could facilitate eligibility for kidney transplantation.
results_summary: The patient lost over 30 kg in 6 months (BMI reduced from 48 to 32 kg/m²), enabling activation on the kidney transplant waiting list. The study suggests bariatric surgery is effective for weight loss in obese adolescents with kidney failure when other interventions fail.
population_specificity: A 14-year-old female with kidney failure and morbid obesity (BMI 48 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize data on changes in intra-pancreatic fat deposition (IPFD) and total pancreas volume (TPV) following metabolic bariatric surgery and endoscopic bariatric therapy.
results_summary: Metabolic bariatric surgery resulted in significant reductions in IPFD (mean absolute reduction of 3.9%) and TPV (mean decrease of 10.7 cm³), with sleeve gastrectomy showing a higher relative IPFD reduction than Roux-en-Y gastric bypass. Follow-up duration analysis suggested benefits manifest more fully after 3 months.
population_specificity: Humans undergoing metabolic bariatric surgery (specific demographics not detailed).
study_duration: Follow-up durations varied, with some studies reporting less than 3 months and others longer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare revision surgery rates after ankle arthroplasty and arthrodesis in patients with and without a history of bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery history did not significantly affect joint infection, instrumentation removal, or ORIF outcomes after ankle procedures, but it was associated with a higher likelihood of adjacent joint fusion after arthrodesis. No differences were observed in surgical outcomes after arthroplasty between the groups.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent primary ankle arthroplasty or arthrodesis, with or without a history of bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between bariatric surgery and kidney stone prevalence using NHANES data.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was associated with a higher prevalence of kidney stones (26.57% vs. 10.92%) and increased odds of kidney stones in both crude and adjusted models. Subgroup analyses showed stronger associations among females and moderately active participants.
population_specificity: 8,087 participants from NHANES (2015-2018), with self-reported bariatric surgery and kidney stone history.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify associations between predominant eating behavior domains and body image distortion/satisfaction in individuals who underwent bariatric surgery in Brazil.
results_summary: Cognitive restriction was the predominant eating behavior domain, with associations found between body image distortion and both cognitive restriction (p = 0.001) and emotional eating (p = 0.001). The study highlighted the importance of researching eating behavior and body image post-surgery.
population_specificity: Individuals in Brazil who underwent bariatric surgery (predominantly female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term efficacy of metabolic and bariatric surgery (MBS) for managing recurrent hypertriglyceridemia-induced acute pancreatitis (HTG-AP) in obese patients.
results_summary: Both LSG and LRYGB groups showed significant weight loss and reduced triglyceride levels, with lower pancreatitis recurrence rates (15.38% and 11.11%, respectively) compared to routine treatment (57.14%). LRYGB resulted in more weight loss than LSG.
population_specificity: 51 obese patients diagnosed with HTG-AP.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of concomitant cholecystectomy (CC) during metabolic and bariatric surgery (MBS) in reducing gallstone formation risk.
results_summary: The study found that CC during MBS increased postoperative complications, including bleeding, wound issues, respiratory problems, and anastomotic complications, though only anastomotic complications were clinically significant. No significant differences were found in operation time, mortality, hospital stay, or vein thrombosis between groups.
population_specificity: 656,830 patients with confirmed gallstones (mean age 41.5 years, 79.2% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the prevalence, clinical implications, and management strategies of micronutrient deficiencies in bariatric surgery patients.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery increases the risk of micronutrient deficiencies, particularly with hypoabsorptive procedures like RYGB and BPD/DS, leading to complications such as anemia and osteoporosis. Effective prevention and management require preoperative correction, continuous monitoring, and tailored supplementation, though long-term adherence remains a challenge.
population_specificity: Patients with severe obesity undergoing bariatric surgery, particularly those with related comorbidities like type 2 diabetes and hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of TXA (tranexamic acid) in managing postoperative bleeding and other outcomes in bariatric surgery.
results_summary: TXA significantly reduced postoperative bleeding, operative time, and length of hospital stay but did not affect hematoma formation, reoperation rates, or transfusion needs. No thromboembolic events or mortality were reported.
population_specificity: 1121 patients undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: To assess the impact of adding an eHealth application to the nutritional preparation process on pre-surgery nutritional knowledge, physical, and behavioral parameters among metabolic bariatric surgery (MBS) candidates.
results_summary: Nutritional knowledge, anthropometrics, functionality, adherence to behavioral recommendations, and subjective health improved in both groups. The intervention group showed higher physical activity initiation, but the application had minimal overall impact on outcomes.
population_specificity: MBS candidates (67.5% women, mean age 34 years, mean BMI 43.5 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 3-6 meetings with a registered dietitian; intervention group also received access to an eHealth application.
study_duration: Duration of nutritional preparation process (exact length not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess all aspects of bariatric surgery in individuals with severe obesity, focusing on effectiveness, outcomes, nutritional management, and complications.
results_summary: The study highlighted significant findings on the effectiveness and outcomes of bariatric procedures, emphasized the importance of comprehensive nutritional management, and noted complications associated with these interventions.
population_specificity: Individuals with severe obesity (within the Tehran Obesity Treatment Study framework).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a machine learning model to predict pregnancy within 12 months after metabolic-bariatric surgery (MBS) to optimize reproductive health services.
results_summary: The study identified 13 key factors influencing pregnancy prediction post-MBS, with the C5.0 decision tree model achieving high accuracy (AUC 0.920). This model can help manage surgical response and pregnancy outcomes.
population_specificity: 473 women with a history of pregnancy after MBS (2009-2023).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a template match algorithm (TMA) for retrospectively identifying unreported meals using continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) data to improve dietary intervention strategies for post-bariatric hypoglycemia (PBH).
results_summary: The TMA correctly identified 1237 out of 1340 meals with 208 false positives, achieving a median F1-score of 0.90, demonstrating its effectiveness in enhancing data quality for managing PBH. The algorithm shows promise for long-term studies and improving PBH management strategies.
population_specificity: 20 PBH subjects monitored in free-living conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of three different anesthetic strategies in reducing postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that opioid-sparing total intravenous anesthesia (PROP+DEX) resulted in fewer rescue antiemetics in the PACU compared to volatile anesthetic with propofol infusion (VOL+PROP), but the antinausea effect did not persist beyond PACU discharge. All groups showed high rates of PONV after PACU discharge, indicating a short-lived benefit of the tested strategies.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery from 2018-2022.
study_duration: Perioperative period (day of surgery and first postoperative day)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of sleeve gastrectomy in an obese patient with Late-onset Pompe disease (LOPD) and explore its potential role in improving clinical outcomes and body composition when other interventions fail.
results_summary: The surgery was well-tolerated without significant complications, with prolonged stability in motor and respiratory functions observed. The patient reported improved quality of life and PROMs following weight loss.
population_specificity: Obese patient with Late-onset Pompe disease (LOPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of metabolic and bariatric surgery (MBS) versus lifestyle modifications (LSM) for weight loss in children and adolescents with severe obesity.
results_summary: MBS resulted in significantly greater reductions in body weight, BMI, and other metabolic markers compared to LSM, along with improved physical functioning and quality of life. The safety profile was comparable between the two groups, though data on safety was limited.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents aged 10-19 years with severe obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze patients' and professionals' experiences with perioperative care in bariatric surgery and develop a framework for long-term follow-up.
results_summary: Participants highlighted the need for a reference professional, psychological support, and financial assistance for physical activity programs, indicating priorities for tailored health services in bariatric surgery management.
population_specificity: Patients awaiting bariatric surgery or who had undergone surgery within the past 1 to 5 years, and health professionals at a bariatric surgery center in southern Portugal.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of socioeconomic deprivation on bariatric surgery outcomes, including weight loss and complications.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in weight loss, complications, or comorbidity outcomes between socioeconomic groups, suggesting that socioeconomic deprivation does not limit bariatric surgery effectiveness.
population_specificity: Patients who received Roux-en-Y Gastric Bypass (RYGB) or Sleeve Gastrectomy (SG) at a regional bariatric center in Scotland (2008-2022).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the critical aspects of nutritional management in bariatric surgery, including preoperative and postoperative strategies, and future research directions.
results_summary: The study highlights bariatric surgery as an effective treatment for obesity, emphasizing the importance of multidisciplinary nutritional management before and after surgery to achieve metabolic control, reduce comorbidities, prevent complications, and ensure long-term success.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of bariatric surgery on female sexual function and the impact of adherence to the Mediterranean diet post-surgery.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery significantly improved female sexual function, reducing preoperative sexual dysfunction from 70.8% to 20.5% after two years. Adherence to the Mediterranean diet was associated with higher scores in lubrication, orgasm, and satisfaction domains.
population_specificity: Heterosexual women with morbid obesity undergoing bariatric procedures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of metabolic and bariatric surgery (MBS) on colorectal cancer (CRC) risk through measures of association such as relative risk (RR) and odds ratio (OR).
results_summary: Meta-analyses showed a significant reduction in CRC risk following MBS in patients with severe obesity, with risk reductions reported by multiple studies. The protective effect was more pronounced in females, and a trend towards reduced rectal cancer risk was noted, though limited by fewer studies.
population_specificity: Patients with severe obesity (53,452,658 patients across 10 systematic reviews).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore post-bariatric surgery changes in energy homeostasis, gut peptides, hormones, and gut microbiota to understand the mechanisms behind weight loss.
results_summary: At three months post-surgery, energy intake, appetite, and anthropometric indices significantly decreased, while PYY and GHR increased. Gut microbiota composition changed significantly, with correlations between taxa and energy homeostasis, BMI, and appetite.
population_specificity: 19 Emirati adults planning to undergo sleeve gastrectomy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the prevalence of metabolic syndrome (MS) remission following bariatric surgery (BS) and compare its efficacy to medical treatment.
results_summary: BS significantly reduced the odds of MS within the first year post-surgery, with greater reductions in patients with lower preoperative BMI and older age. The remission was sustained over 1, 2, and 5 years, and BS was superior to medical treatment in resolving MS.
population_specificity: Patients with metabolic syndrome who underwent bariatric surgery, including subgroups by age, BMI, and ethnicity (e.g., Asians).
study_duration: Follow-up periods included 1, 2, and 5 years post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine long-term changes in Quality of Life (QoL) following abdominoplasty in individuals who had undergone massive weight loss (MWL) after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in physical outcomes (PCS-12) and some psychosocial aspects (vitality, self-acceptance) post-abdominoplasty, but no sustained improvements in mental health (MCS-12), body image (body contact, sexuality, self-esteem), or depression scores (PHQ-4). Body function (X-SMFA) improved long-term, though impairment scores did not change significantly.
population_specificity: 54 post-bariatric patients (mean age 50.8 years) with a BMI < 35 who underwent abdominoplasty after MWL.
study_duration: Not specified (retrospective study with pre- and postoperative assessments).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the dual effects of bariatric surgery on the endocrine system, focusing on its benefits and potential dysfunctions.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery improves metabolic health and hormonal balance but can disrupt insulin-like growth factor-1 recovery, sex hormone balance, and thyroid function, leading to complications like bone loss and hyperinsulinemic hypoglycemia. The study highlights the need for high-quality research to establish causality and refine therapeutic strategies.
population_specificity: Human subjects with obesity and related metabolic disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy, impact on obesity-related complications, risk profiles, and cost-effectiveness of bariatric surgery versus incretin agonist therapies.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was found to be highly effective for sustained weight loss over 10+ years, improving cardiometabolic risk factors (e.g., hyperglycemia, hypertension, dyslipidemia), and reducing all-cause mortality, cardiovascular events, and cancer risk. Observational data supported its long-term benefits, though newer incretin agonists showed comparable efficacy in weight loss and metabolic improvements.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity, including those with associated cardiometabolic conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether zoledronic acid could prevent bone loss in the spine and hip regions following bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Zoledronic acid increased spine bone mass by 2.6% and prevented hip bone loss (-0.6% vs. -3.6% in placebo) at 12 months post-surgery, with statistically significant treatment effects.
population_specificity: 59 patients (73% female, mean age 48.9 years, BMI 42.3) undergoing Roux-en-Y gastric bypass or sleeve gastrectomy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of exercise training in postoperative care for bariatric surgery patients, focusing on outcomes like body weight, fat mass, lean mass, waist circumference, and exercise capacity.
results_summary: Exercise training did not significantly reduce body weight but effectively reduced fat mass, maintained lean mass, and improved waist circumference and exercise capacity in postoperative bariatric surgery patients. The study noted the need for larger-scale trials to confirm these findings and assess long-term impacts.
population_specificity: 1940 patients who underwent bariatric surgery (from 23 included articles).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential benefits and feasibility of combining bariatric surgery (vertical sleeve gastrectomy) with total laparoscopic hysterectomy for patients with obesity and endometrial cancer.
results_summary: The study suggests that bariatric surgery may improve metabolic disease, quality of life, and long-term obesity-related morbidity and mortality in patients with obesity and endometrial cancer, while also potentially reducing lifetime healthcare costs compared to hysterectomy alone. Early evidence supports the combined intervention, but further research is needed.
population_specificity: Women with obesity and early-stage endometrial cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the short-, mid-, and long-term safety and efficacy of metabolic and bariatric surgery (MBS) in patients with a preoperative ASA IV status.
results_summary: The study found that MBS was relatively safe and effective in ASA IV patients, with the greatest weight loss occurring in the BPD-DS cohort (39.5% at 24 months). Major complication rates were 8.4% at 30 days, 6.9% at 90 days, and 14.5% beyond 90 days.
population_specificity: Patients with ASA IV status who underwent sleeve gastrectomy, Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, or biliopancreatic diversion with duodenal switch.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare cardiovascular outcomes between metabolic and bariatric surgery (MBS) and glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonist (GLP-1 RA) therapy in individuals with obesity.
results_summary: MBS was associated with a significantly lower risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD), heart failure (HF), coronary artery disease (CAD), and cerebrovascular disease compared to GLP-1 RA therapy. The hazard ratios for these outcomes ranged from 0.45 to 0.64, indicating substantial risk reduction.
population_specificity: Adult patients with a BMI ≥35.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to estimate the incidence of metabolic and bariatric surgery (MBS) among US adults with obesity, stratified by diabetes status and sociodemographic characteristics.
results_summary: The study found that MBS incidence was nearly threefold higher in adults with obesity and diabetes compared to those without diabetes, with higher rates among women and those with class III obesity. Sleeve gastrectomy was the most common surgical approach, and the Northeast region had the highest incidence.
population_specificity: US non-pregnant adults aged ≥18 years with obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of adjunctive tirzepatide therapy on weight loss and metabolic health in post-bariatric surgery patients with insufficient weight loss or weight regain.
results_summary: Tirzepatide significantly enhanced weight loss (mean 12.0% ± 3.4%), reduced BMI, waist circumference, body fat percentage, and HbA1c, with 100% of patients achieving ≥5% weight loss. Baseline factors like inflammation and body composition predicted outcomes, and fat-free mass loss differed between IWL and WR groups.
population_specificity: Post-bariatric surgery patients without type 2 diabetes who experienced insufficient weight loss or weight regain (n=21).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the outcomes and complications of Metabolic and Bariatric Surgery (MBS) between patients under 50 years old and those 50 years or older.
results_summary: Both age groups showed significant improvements in BMI, cholesterol, and TG levels post-surgery, with younger patients also showing significant improvements in FBS levels. No statistically significant differences in post-surgical complications were observed between the two age groups.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent MBS in a referral hospital in Mashhad, Iran, with at least six months of follow-up (709 patients: 519 ≤50 years, 190 >50 years).
study_duration: Follow-up of at least six months post-surgery.

study_goal: To describe women's experiences of pregnancy after bariatric surgery, focusing on nutrition-related care.
results_summary: Women faced barriers to accessing specialized nutrition care, often due to healthcare professionals' limited understanding of post-bariatric pregnancy needs, leading them to seek information independently and advocate for themselves.
population_specificity: Women aged 26-37 in Australia with a history of bariatric surgery.
study_duration: Interviews conducted after 36-weeks gestation and before childbirth.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of GLP-1 receptor agonists (GLP-1 RAs) in treating suboptimal initial clinical response (SICR) and weight gain recurrence (WGR) after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that GLP-1 RAs (liraglutide, semaglutide, and tirzepatide) significantly improved weight loss outcomes, with tirzepatide showing the highest efficacy. Biochemical markers also improved, and adverse effects were generally mild, with low discontinuation rates due to side effects.
population_specificity: 1,290 patients who underwent bariatric surgery and experienced SICR or WGR.
study_duration: At least 3 months, with some treatments lasting up to 12 months or longer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent findings on managing adverse skeletal effects post-bariatric surgery and summarize guidelines for preventing and treating osteoporosis in this population.
results_summary: Guidelines recommend specific treatments for postmenopausal women and men aged ≥50 years based on fragility fractures and T-scores. Lifestyle changes, sufficient calcium, vitamin D, protein intake, and exercise are crucial. Zoledronic acid is preferred for osteoporosis, with denosumab as an alternative.
population_specificity: People living with obesity (PwO), particularly postmenopausal women and men aged ≥50 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to conduct a systematic bibliometric analysis to explore the relationship between bariatric surgery and gut microbiota, identifying publishing trends and research hotspots.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery significantly alters gut microbiota, which plays a crucial role in postoperative weight loss, and identified "gut microbiota" and "bariatric surgery" as primary research hotspots for future studies.
population_specificity: Global research publications on bariatric surgery and gut microbiota from 1981 to 2024.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the role of preoperative nutritional management in improving bariatric surgery outcomes, focusing on safety, recovery, and long-term compliance.
results_summary: Preoperative nutritional interventions, such as very low-calorie or ketogenic diets, were found to enhance surgical safety, reduce complications, and improve long-term dietary adherence. Addressing nutritional deficiencies and comorbidities before surgery facilitated better recovery and mitigated risks like postoperative weight regain.
population_specificity: Individuals with morbid obesity undergoing bariatric surgery.
effective_dosage: Very low-calorie or ketogenic diets 6-12 weeks before surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess changes in endothelial biomarkers before and after bariatric surgery to understand its cardiometabolic benefits in obesity and type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery led to sustained improvements in glycocalyx and endothelial function biomarkers, with significant reductions in E-Selectin, syndecan-1, and VWF, and an increase in hyaluronan. Weight loss and improved insulin sensitivity were key predictors of these beneficial changes.
population_specificity: Adults with obesity, including 28 with type 2 diabetes and 33 without, undergoing bariatric surgery.
effective_dosage: Roux-en-y gastric bypass preceded by 2 weeks of low-calorie diet (specific calorie amount not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of bariatric surgery in treating severe obesity and its associated comorbidities, focusing on mechanisms, outcomes, and long-term follow-up requirements.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery, including procedures like Roux-en-Y gastric bypass and sleeve gastrectomy, promotes weight loss through anatomical and hormonal changes, improves obesity-related comorbidities, and enhances quality of life, though it requires lifelong medical follow-up to manage potential nutritional deficiencies.
population_specificity: Individuals with severe obesity (BMI ≥ 40 kg/m² or ≥35 kg/m² with comorbidities) who failed conservative management.
study_duration: Lifelong follow-up mentioned, but specific intervention duration not stated.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify gender and racial differences in post-surgical overvaluation of shape/weight (OSW) and excess skin (OES) and their associations with psychosocial outcomes in bariatric surgery patients.
results_summary: Women reported greater OES than men, while White patients had higher OSW than Black patients. Both OSW and OES were linked to poorer quality of life and greater psychological symptoms, particularly in women.
population_specificity: Individuals up to 4 years post-bariatric surgery (n=735).
